Hope this helps!

answers.body_markdown:
The original error most likely originates from a difference in C++ standard flag for the pre-compiled binaries (probably no `-std=c++11`) and your project settings.

For a successful linking against SFML, I recommend:

- Make sure you follow the official tutorial step by step without skipping anything.
- If you link statically:
  - Don't forget to define SFML_STATIC in the project settings
  - Don't forget to link all the dependencies
- Linking order matters, use the [rule of thumb](https://dev.my-gate.net/2018/01/10/rule-of-thumb-linking-order/) "X depends on Y, so X comes before Y"
- And always make sure to use the same compiler version to compile SFML and to build your application

answers.body_markdown:
My theory:

Your presenter is called during your Fragment's `onViewCreated`. But the process to get the item is asynchronous, so while that is happening, the fragment can be quickly detached/stopped/paused/etc. and therefore be in an illegal state to receive updates. It's hard to tell without more context, access to the project, and thorough debugging, but it's a common problem to call back onto a Fragment whose state is invalid. 

There are various ways to mitigate, control, and avoid these issues. Among them, is simply using [LiveData](https://developer.android.com/topic/libraries/architecture/livedata) or even making your presenter Lifecycle Aware, and not calling `view.onItemLoaded(it)` if the fragment lifecycle is "at least" started. 

I don't know if your presenter has an onStop/Destroy/etc. that stops/disposes the subscription in your composite disposables pool, but if the fragment is not ready to receive the response it requested, then the fragment should let the presenter know that it's no longer ready to receive that and that is should be discarded/stopped/etc. If you use Lifecycle/Livedata, this is handled by you, provided you wire the things required for it to work.

I suggest looking at the various [Jetpack](https://developer.android.com/jetpack) components offered by Google.

answers.body_markdown:
Intel architectures call this the Instruction Pointer, instead of Program Counter.&nbsp; Either name refers to the same thing: a register that identifies the address of the current/next instruction for the processor to execute.  

Oversimplifying a bit (i.e.assuming s non pipelined processor) at the beginning of a clock cycle, the PC holds the address of the instruction that will execute during the clock cycle, aka the current instruction.&nbsp; By the end of the clock cycle, the PC register is updated to hold the address of the instruction that will execute in the *next* clock cycle.

`PC = PC + 4` describes sequential execution as used by, say, `add`, `addi`, and by not-taken conditional branches: it says that the *next* PC will refer to the instruction 4 bytes beyond the current one &#8212; that for (normal) sequential flow, the PC steps forward 4 bytes at a time.

The expression `PC = PC + 4 + branch address` is somewhat of a misnomer &#8212; it should say `PC = PC + 4 + offset` where offset is the immediate in the I-Type instruction, more specifically the signed (sign extended from 16-bits to 32-bits) immediate * 4.

In this formula, the `PC` on the right hand side of the `=` refers to the current instruction: the address of the `beq` instruction, while the `PC` on the left hand side refers to the *next* PC to execute after the `beq`. &nbsp; This formula describes the instruction address to execute next when the branch is taken, as this is a conditional branch (if the branch is not taken then `PC = PC + 4` describes sequential execution).

For conditional branches, a value for the immediate of -1 will branch to self, 0 will branch to the next instruction, and 1 will skip one instruction ahead.

answers.body_markdown:
You've not provided enough details. 
Please follow [the official guide][1].

To put it short:

1. You need to ensure that your webpack configuration is valid. It is located in the `webpack.mix.js` file
2. Install all required npm modules `npm install`
3. Compile your assets `npm run watch`. This command will keep track of changes in your asset files and recompile them.
4. Include compiles assets (usually located at `public/css/style.css`) in your base layout or page template (`Blade` template). Usually this is done in the base layout file so it gets included on every page. Like that `<link href="{{ asset('/css/style.css') }}" rel="stylesheet">`

This should solve the issue.


  [1]: https://laravel.com/docs/5.8/mix

```
+---------+---------+
| Value A | Value B |
+---------+---------+
| 10       |       1 |

```
and I want to fill these the missing values with previous values but shifted like shown below.

```

+---------+---------+
| Value A | Value B |
+---------+---------+
| 10       |       1 |
| 20       |       1 |
| 30       |       2 |
| 40       |       2 |
| 50       |       3 |
| 60       |       3 |
| 70       |       4 |
| 80       |       4 |
| 90       |       5 |
| 100      |       5 |

```
The problem is that I these missing values could be in either column. I tried to do it manually but that would take a lot of time. Also filling values depend on ```len()``` of the column A. My approach was something like this:

```
missing_data_len = len(valueA)-len(valueB)
```

answers.body_markdown:
If I understood your question correctly

 - you are trying to logout but once the app refreshes you are logged-in
 - also sometime you need to refresh to get email and id

This is a pretty common issue, underrated I must say, Modern browsers does not really delete the site data until force refreshed/reopened etc etc...

To counter this issue, i will recommend you to keep the same logic to delete the cookies but swap the data structure and conditional logic to check the login activity.

So change your storage from 

    id = ...
    email = ......

to


    userData: {
      id: ....,
      email: ......
    }


you will have to use JSON.parse while reading the cookie and JSON.stringify to save the data

But this much efforts for what ? what would you gain ?

 - Organised User Information
 - **Handing the issue of cookie not getting deleted** - by setting the cookie to  


     userData: {}

    and then deleting it
    and while logging-in checking if id and email exist is userData using hasProperty method if Js



 - A controlled user information which can store and process (using a js util you write in react) more attributes (maybe session storage or server validation etc etc)

 - Encrypting all the user data if you are into that sort of security thing

I hope I gave you an approach to work on and tackle the issue in a systematic way :-)

Also remember to check if the cookie do not exist then to set it blank.
answers.title: Weird cookies behaviour in a ReactJS application

answers.body_markdown:
On logout, you are deleting the cookies but not updating the Redux state.  
Remove the `email` and `id` from redux state.

But the better way is to move this whole cooked management to reducer:

i.e. 

*  reducer should set the initial state by examining cookies
*  on `LOGIN` action, reducer should set the cookies in addition to updating the state
*  on `LOGOUT` action, reducer should delete the cookies in addition to updating the state

Rest of your code should check logged in status only from redux state.  
This way, you will have a single source of truth.

answers.body_markdown:
The problem is this line:

<!-- language-all: python -->

    if lst[i] > lst[i + 1]:

no matter what *reverse* value will be, the operator will always be *greater* (***>***), while in some cases (depensing on *reverse*) you need the *lower* (***<***) one. <br>The easiest way of achieving this is replacing the operator with a function that does the comparison, and that function also takes *reverse* into account. Here's an example that uses *lambda*.

*code00.py*:

    #!/usr/bin/env python3

    import sys
    #import operator


    def bubble_sort(unsorted, reverse=False):
        compare_func = (lambda x, y: x < y) if reverse else (lambda x, y: x > y)  # Create a separate function depending the value of reverse, so it's not checked every time the function is called
        #compare_func = operator.lt if reverse else operator.gt  # Use operator instead of lambdas
        lst = unsorted[:]  # Create a copy of the list
        swapped = True
        while swapped:
            swapped = False
            for i in range(len(lst) - 1):
                if compare_func(lst[i], lst[i + 1]):
                    lst[i], lst[i + 1] = lst[i + 1], lst[i]
                    swapped = True
        return lst


    def main():
        l = [2, 6, 9, 1, 4, 7]
        reverse = False
        print("Reverse: {0:}\n  List: {1:}".format(reverse, bubble_sort(l, reverse=reverse)))
        reverse = True
        print("Reverse: {0:}\n  List: {1:}".format(reverse, bubble_sort(l, reverse=reverse)))


    if __name__ == "__main__":
        print("Python {0:s} {1:d}bit on {2:s}\n".format(" ".join(item.strip() for item in sys.version.split("\n")), 64 if sys.maxsize > 0x100000000 else 32, sys.platform))
        main()
        print("\nDone.")


**Notes**:

- I had to modify your code a bit
- I also incorporated [\[Python 3.Docs\]: operator - Standard operators as functions](https://docs.python.org/3/library/operator.html) usage (the commented lines) instead of *lambda*s. Many might say that this variant is much clearer

**Output**:

<!-- language-all: lang-bat -->

>     [cfati@CFATI-5510-0:e:\Work\Dev\StackOverflow\q058256197]> "e:\Work\Dev\VEnvs\py_064_03.07.03_test0\Scripts\python.exe" code00.py
    Python 3.7.3 (v3.7.3:ef4ec6ed12, Mar 25 2019, 22:22:05) [MSC v.1916 64 bit (AMD64)] 64bit on win32

>     Reverse: False
      List: [1, 2, 4, 6, 7, 9]
    Reverse: True
      List: [9, 7, 6, 4, 2, 1]

>     Done.

answers.title: Object in Synchronized code returned from a method

answers.body_markdown:
`someGetMethod()` is an expression that is evaluated before the monitor associated with the result of the expression is locked by a thread.

> [14.19. The synchronized Statement][1]
> ---
> **A synchronized statement is executed by first evaluating the Expression.** Then:

> - If evaluation of the Expression completes abruptly for some reason, then the synchronized statement completes abruptly for the same reason.

> - Otherwise, if the value of the Expression is null, a NullPointerException is thrown.

> - Otherwise, let the non-null value of the Expression be V. **The executing thread locks the monitor associated with V. Then the Block is executed**, and then there is a choice:

>  - If execution of the Block completes normally, then the monitor is unlocked and the synchronized statement completes normally.

>  - If execution of the Block completes abruptly for any reason, then the monitor is unlocked and the synchronized statement completes abruptly for the same reason.

You can't enter a synchronized block, evaluate the expression, and then look the monitor associated with the result. *How did* you enter the block without evaluating its expression in the first place? *What monitor* did you use to synchronise `someGetMethod()` itself?

  [1]: https://docs.oracle.com/javase/specs/jls/se13/html/jls-14.html#jls-14.19

answers.body_markdown:
A little explanation to clarify my comment. Assuming your `dataframe` looks like
```python
df = pd.DataFrame({'col1': [12, 14, 87, 16, 90]})
```
you could do
```python
def check_in_range(v, lower_lim, upper_lim):
    if lower_lim < v <= upper_lim:
       return True
    return False

lower_lim, upper_lim = 5, 20
for i, v in enumerate(df['col1']):
    if not check_in_range(v, lower_lim, upper_lim):
        print(f"value {v} at index {i} is out of range!")

# --> gives you
value 87 at index 2 is out of range!
value 90 at index 4 is out of range!
```
So your check function is basically fine. However, if you call to `enumerate` a `df`, the values will be the column names. What you need is to enumerate the specific column.

Concerning your idea to raise an exception, I'd suggest to have a look at [raise](https://stackoverflow.com/a/24065533/10197418) and [assert](https://stackoverflow.com/a/5142453/10197418).

So you could e.g. use `raise`:
```python
for i, v in enumerate(df['col1']):
    if not check_in_range(v, lower_lim, upper_lim):
        raise ValueError(f"value {v} at index {i} is out of range")

# --> gives you
ValueError: value 87 at index 2 is out of range
```
or `assert`:
```python
for i, v in enumerate(df['col1']):
    assert v > lower_lim and v <= upper_lim, f"value {v} at index {i} is out of range"

# --> gives you
AssertionError: value 87 at index 2 is out of range
```
**Note:** If you have a `df`, why not use its features for convenience? To get the *in-range* values of the column, you could just do
```python
df[(df['col1'] > lower_lim) & (df['col1'] <= upper_lim)]

# --> gives you
   col1
0    12
1    14
3    16
```

answers.body_markdown:
Did you try to set a [shutdown script](https://cloud.google.com/compute/docs/instances/create-start-preemptible-instance#handle_preemption) and to print something in a file for validating the state of the VM when it goes down ?

Try this as shutdown script
```
#!/bin/bash

curl "http://metadata.google.internal/computeMetadata/v1/instance/preempted" -H "Metadata-Flavor: Google" > /tmp/preempted.log
```
If there is TRUE in the file, it's because the VM has been preempted.
answers.title: GCP VM consistently shutting down without warning

answers.body_markdown:
If a VM stops and you have an active SSH connection to that VM (via `gcloud compute ssh`), then it's normal that you are receiving an error. Since the VM goes down, all connections are closed, so does your SSH connection (you cannot connect to a stopped instance). The VM termination causes the SSH error, not the opposite.

When using preemptible instances, Google can reclaim the instance whenever it's needed. Note that ([from the docs about preemptible instances limitations](https://cloud.google.com/compute/docs/instances/preemptible#limitations)) :

> Compute Engine might terminate preemptible instances at any time due to system events. The probability that Compute Engine will terminate a preemptible instance for a system event is generally low, but might vary from day to day and from zone to zone depending on current conditions.

It means that one day, your instance may be running for 24 hours without being terminated, but an other day, your instance may be stopped 30 minutes after being started if Compute Engine needs to reclaim some resources.
answers.title: GCP VM consistently shutting down without warning

You can use [this](https://bartsimons.me/installing-parallels-tools-on-ubuntu-18-04/) instruction. It's for Ubuntu, but i think this will suit for you.

Summarily:
Download [this](https://kernel.ubuntu.com/~kernel-ppa/mainline/v4.14.39/linux-headers-4.14.39-041439_4.14.39-041439.201806051201_all.deb), [this](https://kernel.ubuntu.com/~kernel-ppa/mainline/v4.14.39/linux-headers-4.14.39-041439-generic_4.14.39-041439.201806051201_amd64.deb), [this](https://kernel.ubuntu.com/~kernel-ppa/mainline/v4.14.39/linux-image-unsigned-4.14.39-041439-generic_4.14.39-041439.201806051201_amd64.deb), and [this](https://kernel.ubuntu.com/~kernel-ppa/mainline/v4.14.39/linux-modules-4.14.39-041439-generic_4.14.39-041439.201806051201_amd64.deb) packages from [here](http://kernel.ubuntu.com/~kernel-ppa/mainline/v4.14.39/) and install it (`sudo dpkg -i *.deb` command)

After it you need purge default kernel (usually it 5.x version, if no, change):

    sudo apt purge linux-headers-5* linux-image-5* linux-modules-5* linux-modules-extra-5*

And now reboot VM and try to install Parallels Tools. If you get error again, try:

    sudo apt install libelf-dev

answers.body_markdown:
This is probably caused by you (or some third party) resolving object graphs directly from the root `IServiceProvider`, instead of resolving it from an `IServiceScope`. Disposable transients are referenced inside the scope so they can be disposed when the scope ends. When you resolve from the root container, however, the root container becomes *the scope*, and those disposable transients are referenced inside the root container, and will only get removed when the root container is disposed. The root container, however, only gets disposed when the application ends.

Long story short: Never resolve from the root container when using MS.DI.

answers.body_markdown:
`extern "C"` just applies to the linkage of the symbol, it doesn't otherwise change the rules of C++.

If it's UB in C++ (and it is), then it's UB, putting it in an `extern "C"` function doesn't change that. The body of the function is still bound by the rules of C++ if it's compiled by a C++ compiler.

However if you have the body of the function in a separate library (or even CU) compiled with C, then the body of the function is bound by C rules. I cannot say with certainty, but I think this is UB in C also.

There's popular russian NLP analyzer called PyMorphy2 which handles lemmatization or POS exceptionally well in particular, however he's not doing so great with english at the moment.
Goal is to to return lemma+POS glued together if it's russian word. otherwise it throws TypeError by default (cant recognize POS of english words) so trying to add exception handler, the code is like this:

    from nltk import sent_tokenize, word_tokenize, regexp_tokenize
    from pymorphy2 import MorphAnalyzer
    
    def preprocess(sent, pat=r"\b\w\w+\b", morph=MorphAnalyzer()):
        try:
            tok = [morph.parse(t)[0].normal_form+morph.parse(t)[0].tag.POS
                   for t in regexp_tokenize(sent, pat)]
        except TypeError:
            tok = [t for t in regexp_tokenize(sent, pat)]
        return tok

**Actual:**

    preprocess("я вижу кто-то наступил на грабли")

['видетьVERB', 'ктоNPRO', 'тоCONJ', 'наступитьVERB', 'наPREP', 'граблиNOUN']

    preprocess("я вижу кто-то наступил на грабли hello")


['вижу', 'кто', 'то', 'наступил', 'на', 'грабли', 'hello']

**Temporary (and funny) solution:**

    tok = [morph.parse(t)[0].normal_form+str(morph.parse(t)[0].tag.POS)
                   for t in regexp_tokenize(sent, pat)]

['видетьVERB', 'ктоNPRO', 'тоCONJ', 'наступитьVERB', 'наPREP', 'граблиNOUN', 'helloNONE']

**Expected:**

    preprocess("я вижу кто-то наступил на грабли hello")


['видетьVERB', 'ктоNPRO', 'тоCONJ', 'наступитьVERB', 'наPREP', 'граблиNOUN', 'hello']

answers.body_markdown:
To get to understand how AutoAnnotation and Dagger 2 works, first I need to understand AutoValue

https://stackoverflow.com/questions/58286591/autovalue-sample-error-cannot-find-symbol-class-autovalue-animal

Then follow by AutoAnnotation

https://stackoverflow.com/questions/58262660/what-is-autoannotation-for-how-could-it-be-used

After that, then I could explore the Dagger 2 example above with AutoAnnotation. 

In short, AutoAnnotation is a Java code generator library that generate value-equivalent Annotation Key that could be used for multi-binding works (since Java classes are not like Kotlin Data Class, hence need such tool to make it value-equivalent easier).

The example given by Google's AutoValue document is not working out of the box. Several modification needed e.g.
1. Have to make the MyComponentTest public, as well as the function.
2. The AutoAnnotation code shouldn't be in the test folder, but in the actual source folder.
3. In order for AutoAnnotation to work with Dagger 2, we'll need the below setting

```
android.defaultConfig.javaCompileOptions.annotationProcessorOptions.includeCompileClasspath = true
```

I have made an example code in https://github.com/elye/demo_android_dagger_autoannotation
